Principal InvestigatorHaig H. Kazazian, Jr, MDUniversity of Pennsylvania School of Medicine, Philadelphia, PA, USA
Funding Source5-R01-GM-066695-03National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD, USA
Configuration.StudyNameReportPage: High-Throughput LINE-1 Retrotransposon Discovery in Humans
Configuration.Description: The aim of this study is to discover LINE-1 (L1) insertion sites present in humans that are absent from the reference genome sequence. We use the distinguishing nucleotide characteristics of human-specific L1 elements to resequence the L1 3' flanking regions thus locating the L1 insertion sites whether or not they are present in the reference genome assembly. In doing so, we have uncovered a higher than expected number of non-reference L1 insertions, an average of 152 insertions per individual. In addition, we find that any two individuals differ at an average of 285 sites with respect to presence or absence of L1 insertions in those sites, and use this to estimate the rate of retrotransposition in humans at 1 event per 140 live births (95% c.i. 1/95 to 1/270). We show that individual 'L1 profiles' recapitulate genetic ancestry as expected, and find that dimorphic insertions are more frequent in introns relative to fixed insertions.

Configuration.StudyHistory: After the study was initiated in 2007, the technique was optimized through several iterations until 2009. The first manuscript describing the work was prepared in 2010.

ConsentGroup.longName: Subjects did not participate in the study, did not complete a consent document and are included only for the pedigree structure and/or genotype controls, such as HapMap subjects.

DacInfo.DacFullName: National Institute of General Medical Sciences DAC

ParticipantSet.UseLimitation: These data will be used only for research purposes. They will not be used to determine the individual identity of any person or of their relationship to another person.

Document.DisplayName: Protocol for retrotransposon insertion site discovery via Illumina sequencing
